messages.content:
Pourquoi Pas Island, situated off the west coast of Graham Land in West Antarctica, has been a valuable site for research, particularly concerning relative sea level changes and marine conditions, as evidenced by its raised beaches [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQGxVgkbk85UqtSO80ToIj1MEax9FzgknCaH-B9KQYQU-dxfUNy-TBIzmMqPlS4pZtR1B8e-LAKHvpLPgGfspu_1P6KAWVjgceQA0K-_eog3zJDcy7R_sRvuewoWi5lhBmDUzrOXpv9utFthzdm-eA7zGRsS) [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQFgSZlcGGlmSP5yg3y3qt5n3XomH04qJkwpQ2aHpnYApHGu9cWDfBmhtWuSYx2bGQIAtlKSVpy66CYHEt1bAFEP2sA7DdZXf6dwNXpYFu9Gk6w_qLlXl8WPWxXIHe4XRWqqc0mWdTFmO9hhSuh8u4Syg22tZDZF1OzLBa6WU4gGTu0NijI_wg_2HNLQnI9fGHbXplWA3rbu8w71qIyHeQ1npFovwSiwJRR5j0l5hghpeCvJNv5rhZmG9FlKM8F7MN5lCX6wcF5AdAyWNf-U7DD_pe-EHOE_R2xVN0ILnjoGDthxk3N6cK8JKA==) [tandfonline](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQE8Yf83IhxPczjlF0dloN__HH2WsBmvPkYgxfrZUPRC5vX2UuGXZVsV4X7-NGpDkjTrlIOoUzl9HAUIZ49PV6p2lvaBjxTDlcUJsn9uDr2Q6cQGTLMxEnDClfMHjOuJ14OB4XUNi9AIz2hvGh4LC_qTNMDzFD7aI5SEHGv1) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQH1tppcQeZDGi3sWqIN-2PI_FSmCfa_NijWIJAIi1qE93K9_RGMxWz1GfJhFkrQCELb6CTHTdj9rDiPaYoELjsRFnimZVEy9Keg0Oq90bqrhqfEk6cjV_pFbpV55XSyFIy6x8Ur3iuqgFZqhmj31AX4c-vX2G_B2ilPOkZCneQnsw==). These beaches have revealed several key insights into the island's past.

The highest raised beaches reach 40 m above sea level and were formed after 9 ka BP (9,000 years before present) [uniovi](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQFmC2uUaMF2zkqhf8Tf21-IrGhe1sYXoCbSiZYNVQQacJC7GmQwQI7HmYIRdAgZGNlLlpWxkxEqX8Exb3K-eYdRhLbaC2sxKHZElCHbdePAMjdmqkJJVK_JvYNhY4wY2eSbu0GerFI5IU6Axv61B4OKuvAyzE0aC7GbnPX9BDVP5XhyFWkBooZUKLvgP9Sb-d_tli7yV4PSRsp_FBGRMHliIGs5ziTPJhkYSgGbBy_e7TZ-). Uplift rates between 7.4 and 2.7 ka BP ranged between 2.7 mm/yr and 4.1 mm/yr [uniovi](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQFmC2uUaMF2zkqhf8Tf21-IrGhe1sYXoCbSiZYNVQQacJC7GmQwQI7HmYIRdAgZGNlLlpWxkxEqX8Exb3K-eYdRhLbaC2sxKHZElCHbdePAMjdmqkJJVK_JvYNhY4wY2eSbu0GerFI5IU6Axv61B4OKuvAyzE0aC7GbnPX9BDVP5XhyFWkBooZUKLvgP9Sb-d_tli7yV4PSRsp_FBGRMHliIGs5ziTPJhkYSgGbBy_e7TZ-). Relative sea level high stands of 40.79 m above present occurred sometime after 9000 cal yr BP, suggesting a thicker ice sheet with grounded ice streams was present compared to sites further north [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQFrKc4VRqI5ITKmH_1ry9gKFZvcPDO-YiNagDHQu1TntHze5DxtaFUpuRZZV85ywTkh_dzPVQRqgS2o-_F6zRk3UuA-Yt1APv8oJg1m50zMGbVJeVrCvt6xeft1vzWJAvcVSux0_-DWWrnfEP5M5DPPoyNdW35MBeMXhq8Ky-ivWKwpjip4BxKylXjyLRxqiGP8Dp4xDDX8DGjbcQQ1e-bL1BSX9CkxrtfQLhoknKMDkKI63H8kcBBV-hD6UmyikAFhAS8vzjk-1QoKaz7vRy_SBY4VezDBiIHdwZ24OXhS0bFlKJJZulgdyQ==) [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQGxVgkbk85UqtSO80ToIj1MEax9FzgknCaH-B9KQYQU-dxfUNy-TBIzmMqPlS4pZtR1B8e-LAKHvpLPgGfspu_1P6KAWVjgceQA0K-_eog3zJDcy7R_sRvuewoWi5lhBmDUzrOXpv9utFthzdm-eA7zGRsS) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQH1tppcQeZDGi3sWqIN-2PI_FSmCfa_NijWIJAIi1qE93K9_RGMxWz1GfJhFkrQCELb6CTHTdj9rDiPaYoELjsRFnimZVEy9Keg0Oq90bqrhqfEk6cjV_pFbpV55XSyFIy6x8Ur3iuqgFZqhmj31AX4c-vX2G_B2ilPOkZCneQnsw==]. The Narrows Lake basin's isolation indicates a rapid fall in relative sea level to 19.41 m by 7270 cal yr BP [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQFrKc4VRqI5ITKmH_1ry9gKFZvcPDO-YiNagDHQu1TntHze5DxtaFUpuRZZV85ywTkh_dzPVQRqgS2o-_F6zRk3UuA-Yt1APv8oJg1m50zMGbVJeVrCvt6xeft1vzWJAvcVSux0_-DWWrnfEP5M5DPPoyNdW35MBeMXhq8Ky-ivWKwpjip4BxKylXjyLRxqiGP8Dp4xDDX8DGjbcQQ1e-bL1BSX9CkxrtfQLhoknKMDkKI63H8kcBBV-hD6UmyikAFhAS8vzjk-1QoKaz7vRy_SBY4VezDBiIHdwZ24OXhS0bFlKJJZulgdyQ==) [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQGxVgkbk85UqtSO80ToIj1MEax9FzgknCaH-B9KQYQU-dxfUNy-TBIzmMqPlS4pZtR1B8e-LAKHvpLPgGfspu_1P6KAWVjgceQA0K-_eog3zJDcy7R_sRvuewoWi5lhBmDUzrOXpv9utFthzdm-eA7zGRsS) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQH1tppcQeZDGi3sWqIN-2PI_FSmCfa_NijWIJAIi1qE93K9_RGMxWz1GfJhFkrQCELb6CTHTdj9rDiPaYoELjsRFnimZVEy9Keg0Oq90bqrhqfEk6cjV_pFbpV55XSyFIy6x8Ur3iuqgFZqhmj31AX4c-vX2G_B2ilPOkZCneQnsw==].

Variations in clast roundness among the raised beaches suggest different phases of wave activity, influenced by changes in summer sea ice cover [uniovi](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQFmC2uUaMF2zkqhf8Tf21-IrGhe1sYXoCbSiZYNVQQacJC7GmQwQI7HmYIRdAgZGNlLlpWxkxEqX8Exb3K-eYdRhLbaC2sxKHZElCHbdePAMjdmqkJJVK_JvYNhY4wY2eSbu0GerFI5IU6Axv61B4OKuvAyzE0aC7GbnPX9BDVP5XhyFWkBooZUKLvgP9Sb-d_tli7yV4PSRsp_FBGRMHliIGs5ziTPJhkYSgGbBy_e7TZ-) [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQGxVgkbk85UqtSO80ToIj1MEax9FzgknCaH-B9KQYQU-dxfUNy-TBIzmMqPlS4pZtR1B8e-LAKHvpLPgGfspu_1P6KAWVjgceQA0K-_eog3zJDcy7R_sRvuewoWi5lhBmDUzrOXpv9utFthzdm-eA7zGRsS). Increased wave activity, potentially due to reduced sea ice, occurred after 8.9 ka BP at Calmette Bay [uniovi](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQFmC2uUaMF2zkqhf8Tf21-IrGhe1sYXoCbSiZYNVQQacJC7GmQwQI7HmYIRdAgZGNlLlpWxkxEqX8Exb3K-eYdRhLbaC2sxKHZElCHbdePAMjdmqkJJVK_JvYNhY4wY2eSbu0GerFI5IU6Axv61B4OKuvAyzE0aC7GbnPX9BDVP5XhyFWkBooZUKLvgP9Sb-d_tli7yV4PSRsp_FBGRMHliIGs5ziTPJhkYSgGbBy_e7TZ-), and beach clasts indicate a period of increased wave energy around 8000 yr BP [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQFrKc4VRqI5ITKmH_1ry9gKFZvcPDO-YiNagDHQu1TntHze5DxtaFUpuRZZV85ywTkh_dzPVQRqgS2o-_F6zRk3UuA-Yt1APv8oJg1m50zMGbVJeVrCvt6xeft1vzWJAvcVSux0_-DWWrnfEP5M5DPPoyNdW35MBeMXhq8Ky-ivWKwpjip4BxKylXjyLRxqiGP8Dp4xDDX8DGjbcQQ1e-bL1BSX9CkxrtfQLhoknKMDkKI63H8kcBBV-hD6UmyikAFhAS8vzjk-1QoKaz7vRy_SBY4VezDBiIHdwZ24OXhS0bFlKJJZulgdyQ==). Parvenu Point became ice-free by 9.6–8.8 ka BP [uniovi](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQFmC2uUaMF2zkqhf8Tf21-IrGhe1sYXoCbSiZYNVQQacJC7GmQwQI7HmYIRdAgZGNlLlpWxkxEqX8Exb3K-eYdRhLbaC2sxKHZElCHbdePAMjdmqkJJVK_JvYNhY4wY2eSbu0GerFI5IU6Axv61B4OKuvAyzE0aC7GbnPX9BDVP5XhyFWkBooZUKLvgP9Sb-d_tli7yV4PSRsp_FBGRMHliIGs5ziTPJhkYSgGbBy_e7TZ-], with marine sedimentation in The Narrows beginning before 8850 cal yr BP [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQGxVgkbk85UqtSO80ToIj1MEax9FzgknCaH-B9KQYQU-dxfUNy-TBIzmMqPlS4pZtR1B8e-LAKHvpLPgGfspu_1P6KAWVjgceQA0K-_eog3zJDcy7R_sRvuewoWi5lhBmDUzrOXpv9utFthzdm-eA7zGRsS) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQH1tppcQeZDGi3sWqIN-2PI_FSmCfa_NijWIJAIi1qE93K9_RGMxWz1GfJhFkrQCELb6CTHTdj9rDiPaYoELjsRFnimZVEy9Keg0Oq90bqrhqfEk6cjV_pFbpV55XSyFIy6x8Ur3iuqgFZqhmj31AX4c-vX2G_B2ilPOkZCneQnsw==].

Researchers have surveyed these beaches, determining coastal conditions from clast size and roundness, and analyzing lake sediments through radiocarbon dating and various methods [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQGxVgkbk85UqtSO80ToIj1MEax9FzgknCaH-B9KQYQU-dxfUNy-TBIzmMqPlS4pZtR1B8e-LAKHvpLPgGfspu_1P6KAWVjgceQA0K-_eog3zJDcy7R_sRvuewoWi5lhBmDUzrOXpv9utFthzdm-eA7zGRsS) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQH1tppcQeZDGi3sWqIN-2PI_FSmCfa_NijWIJAIi1qE93K9_RGMxWz1GfJhFkrQCELb6CTHTdj9rDiPaYoELjsRFnimZVEy9Keg0Oq90bqrhqfEk6cjV_pFbpV55XSyFIy6x8Ur3iuqgFZqhmj31AX4c-vX2G_B2ilPOkZCneQnsw==]. These analyses contribute to understanding the deglaciation and environmental history of the Antarctic Peninsula [tandfonline](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQE8Yf83IhxPczjlF0dloN__HH2WsBmvPkYgxfrZUPRC5vX2UuGXZVsV4X7-NGpDkjTrlIOoUzl9HAUIZ49PV6p2lvaBjxTDlcUJsn9uDr2Q6cQGTLMxEnDClfMHjOuJ14OB4XUNi9AIz2hvGh4LC_qTNMDzFD7aI5SEHGv1) [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQGxVgkbk85UqtSO80ToIj1MEax9FzgknCaH-B9KQYQU-dxfUNy-TBIzmMqPlS4pZtR1B8e-LAKHvpLPgGfspu_1P6KAWVjgceQA0K-_eog3zJDcy7R_sRvuewoWi5lhBmDUzrOXpv9utFthzdm-eA7zGRsS) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQH1tppcQeZDGi3sWqIN-2PI_FSmCfa_NijWIJAIi1qE93K9_RGMxWz1GfJhFkrQCELb6CTHTdj9rDiPaYoELjsRFnimZVEy9Keg0Oq90bqrhqfEk6cjV_pFbpV55XSyFIy6x8Ur3iuqgFZqhmj31AX4c-vX2G_B2ilPOkZCneQnsw==).

search_query: What specific methods were used to analyze the water and rock samples collected from Pourquoi Pas Island in 2024 to assess microplastics, metals, and nutrients?
What were the findings of the studies on lake sediment cores from Pourquoi-Pas Island regarding late-Quaternary environmental change in the Marguerite Bay region?
What data from the raised beaches on Pourquoi-Pas Island revealed about relative sea level change and marine conditions?
web_research_result:
Pourquoi Pas Island is a mountainous island located in West Antarctica, specifically off the west coast of Graham Land [latitude](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-0) [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-1). It lies between Bigourdan Fjord and Bourgeois Fjord [latitude](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-0) [wikishire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-2) [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-1). The island's coordinates are 67°41′S 67°28′W.

Key [kiddle](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-3) [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-1) details about Pourquoi Pas Island:

*   **Size:** The island is 27 km (17 mi) long and 8 to 18 km (5 to 11 mi) wide. Anot [latitude](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-0) [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-1)her source states the island is 17 miles long and from five to eleven miles wide.
*    [wikishire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-2)**Location:** It is situated in the north of Marguerite Bay, between Graham Land and Adelaide Island.
*    [ponant](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-4)**Discovery and Naming:** The French Antarctic Expedition under Jean-Baptiste Charcot discovered the island between 1908 and 1910. Howe [mvdirona](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-5) [wikishire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-2) [expeditions](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-6) [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-1)ver, it wasn't recognized as an island until it was more accurately charted by the British Graham Land Expedition (BGLE) under John Rymill in 1934-1937. Rymi [coolantarctica](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-7) [wikishire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-2) [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-1)ll named the island after Charcot's expedition ship, the *Pourquoi-Pas?*. *Pou [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-1) [wikishire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-2) [coolantarctica](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/0-7)rquoi Pas* means 'Why not' in French.

Pourquoi Pas Island is a mountainous island located off the west coast of Graham Land in West Antarctica, lying between Bigourdan Fjord and Bourgeois Fjord [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-0) [ats](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-1). The island is 27 km (17 mi) long and 8 to 18 km (5 to 11 mi) wide [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-0) [ats](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-1).

The island's history includes:
*   **Discovery:** The French Antarctic Expedition under Jean-Baptiste Charcot discovered the island between 1908 and 1910 [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-0) [expeditions](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-2) [ats](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-1). However, it was not initially recognized as an island [wikishire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-3).
*   **Name:** The island was named in the 1930s by John Rymill of the British Graham Land Expedition (BGLE) [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-0) [finetravel](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-4). He named it after Charcot's expedition ship, *Le Pourquoi Pas?* [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-0) [wikishire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-3) [finetravel](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-4). "Pourquoi pas" means "Why not?" in French [expeditions](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-2). The island may also be named after Maurice Bongrain, FO and surveyor of the Pourquoi Pas ship [ats](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-1).
*   **Charting:** The British Graham Land Expedition charted the island more accurately between 1934 and 1937 [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-0) [wikishire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-3).
*   **Resurvey:** The Falkland Islands Dependencies Survey re-surveyed the island from Stonington Island in 1948-49 [wikishire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-3).

Pourquoi Pas Island is located in the north-east corner of Marguerite Bay on the Fallières Coast in the British Antarctic Territory. [wikishire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-3) It is separated from Blaiklock Island by a channel called the Narrows. [wikishire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-3)

The island is known for its glacial scenery and ice. [ats](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-1) Wildlife includes Adelie penguins, Antarctic fur seals, skuas, Wilson's Storm petrels and Kelp gulls. [ats](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-1) [expeditions](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-2) Occasional visitors include Crabeater seals, Weddell seals, Humpback whales, Killer whales and various Beaked whales. [ats](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/1-1)

Okay, I will conduct Google Searches to gather the most recent, credible information on "Pourquoi Pas Island research expeditions" and synthesize it into a verifiable text artifact.
Pourquoi Pas Island, a mountainous island off the west coast of Graham Land in West Antarctica, has been the subject of various research expeditions [coolantarctica](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-0) [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-1). Discovered by the French Antarctic Expedition (1908-1910) under Jean-Baptiste Charcot, the island was later charted more accurately by the British Graham Land Expedition (1934–1937).  [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-1)The island was named after Charcot's expedition ship, the Pourquoi-Pas.  [coolantarctica](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-0) [wikipedia](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-1)"Pourquoi pas" means 'Why not' in French.
 [expeditions](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-2) [expeditions](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-3)
**Geological Studies:**

Geological reconnaissance mapping has been conducted on Pourquoi Pas Island.  [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-4)The oldest rocks found are granodiorites, overlain by a varied succession of volcanic strata exceeding 1,500 meters.  [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-4)These volcanic strata are part of the Antarctic Peninsula Volcanic Group.  [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-4)The western half of the island features an intrusive complex of Andean plutonic rocks.  [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-4)A wide range of plutonic rocks, from gabbro to granite, are represented in a belt across the west end of the island.  [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-4)Studies of lake sediment cores from Pourquoi-Pas Island, along with Horseshoe Island, provide evidence of late-Quaternary environmental change in the Marguerite Bay region.  [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-5) [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-6)Raised beaches on Pourquoi-Pas Island have also been surveyed to gather information on relative sea level change and marine conditions.
 [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-5)
**Environmental and Climate Change Research:**

Recent research has focused on the impact of tourism and climate change on Antarctica, with Pourquoi Pas Island being one of the locations studied.  [royalnavy](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-7) [port](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-8)In 2024, researchers from the University of Portsmouth collected water and rock samples from Pourquoi Pas Island to analyze microplastics, metals, and nutrients, and to examine glacial advances.  [royalnavy](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-7) [port](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-8)Specifically, rock samples were taken to examine glacial advances during the last 5,000 years.  [royalnavy](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-7)The Royal Navy's HMS Protector has assisted scientists in these research missions.  [royalnavy](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-7) [port](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-8)Studies also use seal populations as indicators of climate change impacts, with observations noting changes in ice conditions around Ryder Bay, near Pourquoi Pas Island.
 [shackleton](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-9)
**Biodiversity Studies:**

Pourquoi Pas Island is also a site for biodiversity research.  [biodiversa](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-10)Bacterial diversity in terrestrial and aquatic microbial mats has been assessed, with one sample collected from Pourquoi Pas Island.  [gbif](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-11)The island's location is approximately 67.66°S, 67.25°W.

* [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-12)*Historical Significance:**

Jean-Baptiste Charcot's second Antarctic voyage included a stay on Petermann Island in 1909, where he erected a cairn with a plaque listing the names of his crew. A  [institut-polaire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-13)replica of this plaque is now an Antarctic Historic Monument and is visited by tourists.
 [institut-polaire](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/2-13)

While I cannot provide information specific to "Pourquoi Pas Island" as of 2024 due to the lack of specific data in the search results, I can offer a general overview of methods used for analyzing water and rock samples for microplastics, metals, and nutrients, based on the provided search snippets.

**Microplastics Analysis:**

*   **Sampling:** Common tools for sampling microplastics in water include manta trawls for surface water and various devices like shovels, trowels, spades, scoops, and spatulas for sediment sampling [nih](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/3-0). Selective, bulk, and volume-reduced sampling strategies are employed [itrcweb](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/3-1) [acs](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/3-2).
*   **Pre-treatment:** Samples often undergo chemical pre-treatment [epa](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/3-3).

Studies of lake sediment cores from Pourquoi-Pas Island in Marguerite Bay have revealed valuable insights into late-Quaternary environmental changes in the region [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-0) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-1) [daneshyari](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-2) [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-3) [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-4). These studies often combine data from lake sediment records with evidence from raised beaches to develop a comprehensive understanding of the past environment [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-1) [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-4) [daneshyari](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-2) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-0).

Key findings from these studies include:

*   **Deglaciation Events:** Evidence suggests possible local deglaciation events occurred around 28,830 (29,370-28,320) cal yr BP, immediately after Antarctic Isotopic Maximum 4, and around 21,110 (21,510-20,730 interpolated) cal yr BP, coinciding with or immediately after Antarctic Isotopic Maximum 2 [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-4) [daneshyari](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-2) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-0).
*   **Holocene Deglaciation:** The Holocene deglaciation of Horseshoe Island commenced around 10,610 (11,000-10,300) cal yr BP, coinciding with the early Holocene temperature maximum recorded in Antarctic ice cores [daneshyari](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-2) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-1) [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-3) [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-4) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-0). Marine sedimentation in The Narrows, Pourquoi-Pas Island, began before 8850 (8480-9260) cal yr BP [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-1) [daneshyari](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-2) [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-4) [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-3) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-0).
*   **Relative Sea Level Changes:** Relative sea level high stands of 40.79 m above present at Pourquoi-Pas Island and 40.55 m above present at Calmette Bay occurred sometime after 9000 cal yr BP, suggesting a thicker ice sheet with grounded ice streams was present in this region compared to sites further north [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-1) [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-3) [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-4) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-0) [daneshyari](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/4-2). The Narrows Lake basin on Pourquoi-Pas Island was isolated as relative sea level fell to 19.41 m by 7270 (7385–7155) cal yr BP.

Raised beaches on Pourquoi-Pas Island, located in Marguerite Bay on the Antarctic Peninsula, provide data on relative sea level change and marine conditions, revealing insights into the region's deglaciation history and past environmental conditions [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-0) [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-1) [tandfonline](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-2) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-3).

**Key Findings from Raised Beaches:**

*   **Glacio-Isostatic Uplift:** The highest raised beaches on Pourquoi-Pas Island reach 40 m above sea level and were formed after 9 ka BP (9,000 years before present) [uniovi](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-4). At least five levels of more recent raised beaches exist between 22 and 4.5 m above sea level [uniovi](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-4). Uplift rates between 7.4 and 2.7 ka BP ranged between 2.7 mm/yr and 4.1 mm/yr [uniovi](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-4).
*   **Relative Sea Level High Stands:** Relative sea level high stands of 40.79 m above present at Pourquoi-Pas Island occurred sometime after 9000 cal yr BP, suggesting a thicker ice sheet with grounded ice streams was present in this region compared to sites further north [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-5) [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-0) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-3).
*   **Sea Level Fall:** Isolation of the Narrows Lake basin on Pourquoi-Pas Island indicates a rapid fall in relative sea level to 19.41 m by 7270 cal yr BP [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-5) [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-0) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-3). Data from Parvenu Point and Narrows Lake suggest a local sea level at 19.4 m at 6.5 ka [cambridge](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-6).
*   **Marine Conditions and Wave Activity:** Differences in clast roundness between raised beaches suggest different phases of wave activity, resulting from variations in summer sea ice cover [uniovi](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-4) [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-0). Periods with enhanced wave activity due to reduced sea ice occurred after 8.9 ka BP at Calmette Bay [uniovi](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-4). Beach clasts provide evidence of a period of increased wave energy at approximately 8000 yr BP [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-5).
*   **Deglaciation Timing:** Parvenu Point on Pourquoi-Pas Island became ice-free by 9.6–8.8 ka BP.  [uniovi](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-4)Cosmogenic nuclide dating, along with radiocarbon dates on lake sediments and raised beaches, indicates that onshore thinning was underway by 18 ka and its main phase ended by 10-9 ka.  [researchgate](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-5)Marine sedimentation in The Narrows began before 8850 cal yr BP.
 [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-0) [nerc](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-3)*   **Lithology:** The underlying bedrock consists of foliated granitic gneisses of the Antarctic Peninsula Metamorphic Complex and undifferentiated volcanic rocks of the Antarctic Peninsula Volcanic Group.  [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-0)The eastern half of the Island consists of volcanic rocks, while the western half consists largely of plutonic rocks intruding volcanic rocks.

**Methods of Study:**

*   Researchers surveyed raised beaches up to their marine limits using a Leica NA720 autoset level.
 [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-0)*   They determined periods of changing coastal conditions from changes in clast size and roundness of raised beach material.
 [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-0)*   Measurements of the a-axis (longest axis) and b-axis (intermediate axis) of rocks were also undertaken.
 [vliz](https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/id/5-0)*   Lake sediments were radiocarbon dated and analyzed using sedimentological, geochemical, and microfossil methods.
